choices.text: With dietary modifications majority of these symptoms will improve
He should separate the ingestion of liquids from solids
Administration of cholestyramine will likely prevent most of his symptoms
None of the surgical treatments of this condition is uniformly successful.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient follows up in your OPD , 1 month after you performed distal gastrectomy with Billroth II reconstruction for his perforated gastric ulcer. The histopathology report does not show any evidence of malignancy. On her follow up visit he no longer has the burning epigastric pain, but complains of bloating and severe abdominal cramps soon after meals, followed by profuse diarrhea, sweating,and dizziness. These symptoms appeared shortly after he recovered from surgery, and have not improved since then. He can be advised all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a case of early dumping syndrome following Bilroth II Distal gastrectomy. Dietary modifications play an important role in improvement of these symptoms. Along with this Octreotide may be helpful but there is no role of Cholestyramine in these patients

choices.text: Antibodies to parietal cells and Intrinsic Factor are seen in gastric secretions.

questions.text: All the following statements about autoimmune gastritis are true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Decreased (not increased) serum pepsinogen is a sensitive and specific marker of gastric atrophy

choices.text: Diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar mucus cells.

questions.text: False about Menetrier’s disease is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There is involvement of body and fundus predominantly in this condition and not antral.

choices.text: PGDFRA (Platelet derived growth factor receptor alpha) mutation
Germline mutation in CDH1 coding for E cadherin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for Adeno Ca stomach
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PGDFRA mutation is associated with GIST and not with Adeno ca of stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following does not affect gastrin release
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The primary factors stimulating gastrin release are vagal stimulation, food in the antrum, and gastric distension. Both polypeptides and amino acids result in increased gastrin release but fats and carbohydrates have no effect. Prolonged alkalinization (>8 h) will increase gastrin release, while acute alkalinization does not directly cause release of gastrin, but does potentiate the release by other stimuli. The primary inhibitor of gastrin release is antral acidification (pH <2.5). Increased acid in the antrum results in somatostatin release from antral D cells, which then inhibits gastrin release.

choices.text: Duodenotomy , oversewing the ulcer, truncal vagotomy and antrectomy
Duodenotomy, oversewing the ulcer, truncal vagotomy, and pyloroplasty
Duodenotomy , oversewing the ulcer and HSV

questions.text: A 50 year old male with a history of peptic ulcer presents to the emergency with haematemesis. Upper GI endoscopy reveals active pulsatile bleeding from a posteriorly located duodenal ulcer. Even after two attempts of controlling the bleeding endoscopically, the bleeding continues. The patient has received four units of blood. His hematocrit is 28%, his pulse rate is 114/min and blood pressure is 112/64 mm Hg. The most appropriate management in this patient should be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Since patient already had two attempts of controlling the bleeding endoscopically , the patient needs a surgery for controlling the bleeding. So along with oversewing the ulcer to control the bleeding, a truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty should be done to treat the ulcer. HSV is not indicated in such emergent scenarios.

questions.text: The most common nutritional deficiency seen after gastric resection is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Iron deficiency anaemia is the most common nutritional deficiency after gastric resection. For deficiency of Vitamin B12, minimum 50% of stomach needs to be resected.

choices.text: Mesenteroaxial volvulus has a more acute presentation.
Organoaxial volvulus is the commonest type.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about gastric volvulus is false
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Meseneteroaxial volvulus the less common of the two types usually is partial(<180 degrees) and recurrent. The organoaxial type usually presents more acutely.

choices.text: Its emergency so do pyloromyotomy immediately

questions.text: A 3 weeks old patient presenting with vomiting and failure to thrive is found to have pyloric stenosis. What should be the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) whenever we have a patient of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis we have to first correct the electrolytes and manage the metabolic alkalosis. Once the patient is stable only then we proceed with the operative procedure. Option A. Pyloromyotomy is to be done once the patient's general condition has been stabilized. Option B. Fluid resuscitation should not be delayed in this condition as the patient has failure to thrive. Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation might be needed if the patient collapses but is not indicated in every case.

choices.text: First born male is commonly affected

questions.text: True about hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D. In patients with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis peristalsis can be visible but it is not present in every patient. Option A. CHPS presents at around 4th week of life with non bilious vomiting and failure to thrive. Visible peristalsis are seen from left to right. Option B. This is correct as the typical history present in the patient is first born male child. Option C. Treatment of choice for CHPS is ramstedt's pyloromyotomy

questions.text: Investigation of choice for CHPS is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Investigation of choice for CHPS is USG. On USG we get thickness of pylorus more than 4 mm and length more than 16 mm. On USG : Target sign , Antral Nipple sign On contrast study : String sign ( seen in image) , Double track sign , Mushroom sign On X-RAY abdomen:-single bubble sign .

questions.text: Gastric conduit is based on ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Gastric conduit is based on right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery. Option B. Left gastric artery is the most common cause of bleed in mallory weiss syndrome Option C. Gastroduodenal artery is the main source of bleeding in posteriorly perforating duodenal ulcer. Option D. Left gastroepiploic is a branch of splenic artery.

choices.text: It is associated with Borchardt triad.
Organoaxial volvulus is associated with diaphragmatic defect
Organoaxial volvulus has less chance of necrosis as compared to mesenteroaxial volvulus.
Mesenteroaxial volvulus tends to be recurrent.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about gastric volvulus ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C. Organoaxial volvulus has more chance of necrosis as compared to mesenteroaxial volvulus. Option A. Gastric volvulus is associated with Borchardt triad: Severe epigastric pain + Retching without vomiting + Inability to pass NG Tube. Option B. Organoaxial volvulus is the one associated with diaphragmatic defect. Mesenteroaxial volvulus is associated with impaired attachments of the stomach with the wall . Option D. Mesenteroaxial volvulus tends to recur

questions.text: Most common site of peptic ulcer is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C. Most common site of peptic ulcer is first part of duodenum. H.pylori is associated with > 90% cases of duodenal ulcer and around 80% cases of gastric ulcer. Option A. Incisura angularis is the most common site of gastric ulcer

questions.text: Which type of gastric ulcer is associated with increased gastric acid secretion.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Johnson gave the classification of gastric ulcers. Type II and Type III are associated with increased gastric acid secretion. Type I occurs at incisura angularis and is the most common type. Type IV occurs along lesser curvature Type V is NSAIDs induced.

questions.text: Percentage of patients with perforated peptic ulcer who show free gas under the diaphragm:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Only 75 % of patients who develop peptic perforation show free gas under diaphragm . Investigation of choice for detecting free gas in peritoneal cavity is CT Scan.

questions.text: Posterior perforation of peptic ulcer drain into:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) If a gastric ulcer perforates posteriorly we have collection in lesser sac also referred to omental bursa. Option D. If gastric ulcer perforates anteriorly then the collection occurs in the peritoneal cavity or the paracolic gutters.

choices.text: Antrectomy with ligation of left gastric artery
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels with postoperative PPI
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, truncal vagotomy and pyloroplasty
Duodenotomy with ligation of bleeding vessels, highly selective vagotomy

questions.text: A 30 years old male presented with massive hematemesis. A 2 × 2 cm ulcer was visualized on upper GI endoscopy on the posterior aspect of first part of duodenum. The bleeding vessel was visualized but bleeding could not be controlled endoscopically. Blood transfusion was done and patient was planned for surgery. His BP was 90/70mmhg and PR=110/min with Hb=9 gm% at the time of surgery. Which of the following would be best surgical management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) As patient is hemodynamically unstable and not a known case of PUD who is on H.pylori treatment hence surgery should be done for control of bleeding with post op PPIs and h.pylori eradication

questions.text: PPI for peptic ulcer disease should be taken:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In a fasting state, only 10% of proton pumps are actively secreting acid and susceptible to inhibition. That is why PPIs should be administered 1 hour before a meal (usually breakfast).

questions.text: Pyloroplasty of choice when the duodenum is fibrosed and contracted?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Finney Pyloroplasty: Performed in patients with a J-shaped stomach or extensive scarring and narrowing of a significant portion of the duodenal bulb. Heineke-Mikulicz Pyloroplasty: Most commonly performed drainage procedure. Jaboulay Gastroduodenostomy: It involves an anastomosis of the distal end of the stomach to the first and second portions of the duodenum, done in severely scarred or deformed pylorus or duodenal bulb. Options B and C . They can be done but have a lot of morbidity when compared to pyloroplasty so not preferred. Option D. It is done for CHPS.

questions.text: Treatment of high lying ulcer near gastroesophageal junction is/are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & C) High lying ulcer near gastroesophageal junction falls into gastric ulcer type IV . Treatment of type IV gastric ulcer is : Schoemaker procedure Pouchet procedure Kelling-Madlener procedure (For unstable patients) Csendes procedure (For stable patients) Options D and E. Vagotomy with pyloroplasty or vagotomy with drainage procedure is done for Type II and III gastric ulcers.

questions.text: Maximal reduction in gastric acidity is achieved by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) There are three types of Vagotomy :- Highly selective Vagotomy: Procedure of choice for chronic or intractable duodenal ulcers.Nerves of Latarjet supplying the antrum are preserved (and hence gastric motility) .Drainage procedure is not required .Lowest Mortality rate and side effects. Minimal chances of dumping syndrome and gastric atony .High recurrence rate. Selective Vagotomy: In this procedure we cut vagus nerve after it has given celiac and hepatic branches. Truncal Vagotomy : TV is performed by division of left and right vagus nerves above the hepatic and celiac branches just above the GE junction. MC operation performed for duodenal ulcer .Procedure of choice for recurrent duodenal ulcers .Lowest recurrence rate. Highest Morbidity and mortality. Truncal Vagotomy can be performed either with drainage procedures like pyloroplasty or with an antrectomy

questions.text: Most common metabolic complication of gastrectomy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MC metabolic complication after gastrectomy is iron deficiency anemia.

choices.text: Clinical features include diarrhea and bloating

questions.text: Which is not true about dumping syndrome? (DNB 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C. Starch is not beneficial for dumping syndrome. Starch actually increases the signs and symptoms of dumping syndrome. Option A. This is true as dumping syndrome is more common in patients who have been subjected to vagotomy. Option B. One of the treatment option for dumping syndrome is eating small frequent meals, this is beneficial for the patients of dumping syndrome as it reduces the amount of hyper osmolar substances entering into the small intestine. Option D. Early dumping syndrome presents with diarrhoea and bloating sensation.

questions.text: Duodenal blow out following Billroth gastrectomy most commonly occurs on which day:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Duodenal stump blowout is massive leakage from duodenal stump following Billroth-II gastrectomy. Clinical Features: It usually occurs on 4th to 7th postoperative day. Usually presents as sudden intense thoracoabdominal pain, sudden elevation in pulse and temperature or generalized deterioration of condition. Treatment: Adequate drainage must be instituted immediately,which is done by putting catheter through an incision below the right costal margin. TPN should be instituted and attention should be directed towards fluid and electrolyte therapy. Fistula closure can be anticipated within 2-3 weeks.

questions.text: A patient who has been operated for billroth type II surgery develops seizures. Patient had taken lunch 3 hours before this episode, when you do the serum blood glucose of the patient value comes out to be 40 mg/dl. What is the diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B. Late dumping syndrome occurs 2 to 3 hours after a meal. It results from excessive movement of sugar into the intestine, which raises the body's blood glucose level and causes the pancreas to increase its release of the hormone insulin. The increased release of insulin causes a rapid drop in blood glucose levels, a condition known as alimentary hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar. Option A. Early dumping syndrome occurs 10 to 30 minutes after a meal. It results from rapid movement of fluid into the intestine following a sudden addition of a large amount of food from the stomach.The small intestine expands rapidly due to the presence of hypertonic or hyperosmolar contents from the stomach, especially sweet foods. This causes symptoms due to the shift of fluid into the intestinal lumen, with plasma volume contraction and acute intestinal distention.Osmotic diarrhea, distension of the small bowel leading to crampy abdominal pain, and reduced blood volume can result. Option C. Duodenal stump blowout usually presents as sudden intense thoracoabdominal pain, sudden elevation in pulse and temperature or generalized deterioration of condition. Option D. Anastomotic leak will come with signs of peritonitis.

questions.text: Most common cause of upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding is: (Recent Questions 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: In the Forest classification for bleeding peptic ulcer with a visible vessel of pigmented protuberance is classified as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Conservative Treatment is effective in most of the cases
Antireflux procedure doesn't have added advantage

questions.text: False about Mallory-Weiss syndrome:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Most common presentation of mallory weiss tear is upper GI bleed but it rarely causes massive bleeding. Option B. Alcohol is associated with mallory weiss tear. Mallory-Weiss Tears Are Related To Forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. Forceful contraction of the abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardia, resulting in mucosal laceration of the proximal cardia as a result of the increase in intragastric pressure.This results in disruption of gastric mucosa high on the lesser curve at cardia (just below GE junction). Tear is partial thickness,extending through the mucosa and submucosa. Option C. Supportive therapy is often all that necessary because 90% of bleeding episodes are self-limited, and the mucosa often heals within 72 hours. Option D. There is no added advantage of antireflux surgery in mallory weiss tear.

choices.text: Angiographic embolization is the preferred treatment

questions.text: All are true about Dieulafoy’s lesion except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Endoscopic control of bleeding is the preferred treatment option in dieulafoy’s lesion. Angiographic embolisation can be tried if endoscopic control fails. Option C and D. Dieulafoy’s lesion occurs because of erosion of the superficial mucosa overlying the artery secondary to the pulsations of the large submucosal vessel or arteriole.

choices.text: Bleeding is the most common presentation
Pain is most common clinical symptoms.
Argon laser treatment is established one.

questions.text: All are true about GAVE except: (JIPMER GIS 2011)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C. Pain is not the most common presenting feature of GAVE (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia) . Most common presenting feature of GAVE is bleeding . Option A. In GAVE ,we have Dilated submucosal Venules affecting antrum.( Body of stomach is spared) Associated with vascular collagen diseases like SLE . Gives appearance like watermelon stomach Option D. The lesions are treated by endoscopic cautery and Argon laser.

questions.text: Watermelon stomach is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In GAVE Gross Endoscopic Examination Reveals Prominent longitudinal folds with parallel striking red stripes at top of the mucosal folds of the distal stomach, much like the rind of a watermelon.

questions.text: Menetrier’s disease is characterized by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ménétrier disease is a rare, acquired, premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, excessive mucus production with resultant protein loss, and little or no acid production. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor alpha (TGF-alpha).

choices.text: H. pylori is a predisposing factor in adults

questions.text: All are true about Menetrier’s disease except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ménétrier disease is a rare, acquired, premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, excessive mucus production with resultant protein loss, and little or no acid production. The disorder is associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor alpha (TGF-alpha).

questions.text: Most common benign tumour of the stomach is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The most common benign lesion of stomach is Leiomyoma

questions.text: The commonest gastric polyp is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common gastric polyp is the hyperplastic or regenerative polyp,which frequently occur in the setting of gastritis. Polyps that are symptomatic, > 2 cm or adenomatous should be removed. Option B. Inflammatory Polyp: A polyp made of inflammatory tissues can be called inflammatory pseudopolyp because glandular tissue is either lost or absent Option C . Adenomatous Polyp : Presence is a marker indicating an increased risk for development of cancer in remainder gastric mucosa.

questions.text: E-cadherin is more often mutated in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lauren's Classification of Gastric Cancer :

questions.text: According to Bormann's classification, Linnitus plastica is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following classification system is used for early gastric cancer ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Japanese classification : Early gastric cancer Bormann Classification : Advanced gastric cancer

questions.text: Level 9 lymph node includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Gastric lymph node station no 5:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Troisier’s sign is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Troisier sign is the clinical finding of a hard and enlarged left supraclavicular node (Virchow node), and is considered a sign of metastatic abdominal malignancy.

questions.text: Sister Joseph’s nodule may indicate cancer of all the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sister mary joseph nodules are seen in : Gastric cancer Colonic cancer Ovarian cancer Uterine cancer Pancreatic cancer (mostly body and tail)

questions.text: Most common site of carcinoma of stomach is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common site of Ca stomach is Gastric Antrum. Option C. Most common site of gastric Ca in pernicious anaemia pts is Fundus of the stomach Option D. Most common site of burkitt's lymphoma is Cardiac region of stomach

questions.text: Presenting symptom of carcinoma stomach is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common presenting feature of Ca stomach patients is weight loss. Options A, B and C. Patients of Gastric Ca can also present with these features but the most common presenting feature is weight loss.

questions.text: Locally invasive gastric carcinoma. Investigation of choice to know depth of cancer invasion:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The best way to stage the tumor locally is via EUS, which gives fairly accurate (80%) information about the depth of tumor penetration into gastric wall and can show enlarged perigastric and celiac lymph nodes.

questions.text: Cell of origin in GIST:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GIST: MC mesenchymal tumor of the GI tract MC primary site for GIST: Stomach (60–70%) > small bowel (20–25%) > colorectum and esophagus (5% each) GIST arises from pacemaker cells of Cajal. Option C. Tumors arising from muscle layer are called leiomyoma. Option D. Tumours arising from epithelium lining the stomach are polyps and carcinoids.

questions.text: False about GIST:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lymphatic spread is uncommon, so routine lymphadenectomy is not recommended. Option A. Most common site of GIST in the body is stomach. It can occur at other parts of GIT as well. Option B. Bleeding can occur in patients of GIST. Bleeding is the MC indication of surgery in patients of GIST. Option D. Metastasis although uncommon but can occur in patients suffering from GIST.

questions.text: Sunitinib is used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sunitinib is an oral, small-molecule, multi-targeted receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) inhibitor that was approved by the FDA for the treatment of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and imatinib-resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)

questions.text: All are true about stomach lymphoma except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) the most common site of stomach lymphoma is antrum not fundus. Option A and B. Most common type of gastric lymphoma is B-Cell Non hodgkin’s lymphoma Option C. Most of the Gastric lymphomas are chemosensitive. Treatment of choice for gastric lymphoma is chemotherapy. R-CHOP regimen is used. R-Rituximab C-Cyclophosphamide H- Hydroxydaunorubicin O-Oncovin/Vincristine P-Prednisolone

questions.text: Treatment of gastric lymphoma includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C, & D) Option A. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice for gastric lymphoma patients. Option B. Radiotherapy can be used to prevent the local recurrence and for residual tumours. Option C. If there occurs some complication of gastric lymphoma which can not be managed by medical treatment then we need to go for surgical intervention . Option D. H.Pylori is strongly associated with gastric lymphoma so eradication of H.pylori infection is a treatment option for gastric lymphoma. Option E. Endoscopic resection is not carried out for Gastric lymphoma.

questions.text: Indication of surgery in gastric lymphoma are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D. For intractable pain we need to consider celiac ganglion block. Indications of Surgery in patients of gastric lymphoma: Failure of chemoradiation Hemorrhage Obstruction Perforation

questions.text: Treatment of choice for localised GIST ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Laparoscopic wedge resection (LWR) is recommended for gastric GIST smaller than 5 cm. Wedge resection of gastric GIST is considered standard treatment and lymphadenectomy is not indicated as nodal metastasis is rare.

questions.text: For high risk cases of GIST of size > 10cm, imatinib therapy is given for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Imatinib, sold under the brand name Gleevec among others, is an oral chemotherapy medication used to treat cancer. Imatinib is given for 3 years for high risk cases of GIST of size >10cm. Specifically, it is used for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) that are Philadelphia chromosome-positive (Ph+), certain types of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST), hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), chronic eosinophilic leukemia (CEL), systemic mastocytosis, and myelodysplastic syndrome. Common side effects include vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain, headache, and rash. Severe side effects may include fluid retention, gastrointestinal bleeding, bone marrow suppression, liver problems, and heart failure. Use during pregnancy may result in harm to the baby. Imatinib works by stopping the BCR-ABL tyrosine-kinase. This can slow growth or result in programmed cell death of certain types of cancer cells.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for duodenal atresia is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Treatment of choice for duodenal atresia is duodenoduodenostomy. Duodenoduodenostomy is also done in Annular Pancreas. Option B. Treatment of choice for SMA syndrome is Duodenojejunostomy Option C. Bishop-koop procedure is used for meconium ileus Option D. Treatment for gastric outlet obstruction is gastrojejunostomy.

choices.text: After gastrectomy it does not occur
Caused by ingestion of fruits, vegetables, fibers and hairs.
In Rapunzel syndrome bezoar has a tail like extension into the small bowel .
It Increases chances of gastric ulceration .

questions.text: True about gastric bezoar:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, C, & E) Option B. Phytobezoar : Most common type, a high concentration of tannin,exposed to gastric acid form a coagulum leading to bezoar formation. Most commonly found in patients who have undergone surgery of the stomach and have impaired gastric emptying. But it can also occur in other parts of the intestine. Diabetics with autonomic neuropathy are also at risk Option C. Rapunzel syndrome is an extremely rare intestinal condition in humans resulting from ingesting hair (trichophagia).The syndrome is named after the long-haired girl Rapunzel in the fairy tale. Trichophagia is sometimes associated with the hair-pulling disorder trichotillomania. This syndrome is a rare and unusual form of trichobezoar. Characteristics of the syndrome include: The body of a trichobezoar (hairball) located in the stomach, and its tail (hence the reference to Rapunzel in the syndrome's name) in the small bowel and/or in the right colon. Option E. As there is a foreign body inside the lumen it increases the chances of gastric ulceration. Option A. It can occur after gastrectomy in other parts of GIT or the remaining gastric stump. Option D. Primary treatment of phytobezoar is Enzymatic therapy attempt dissolution of the bezoar. Papain and cellulase have been used with some success. Generally, enzymatic débridement is followed by aggressive Ewald tube lavage or endoscopic fragmentation. Failure of these therapies would necessitate surgical removal.

questions.text: Which of the following gastric ulcer is associated with blood group A ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Type I gastric ulcer : Associated with blood group A Type II, III and IV gastric ulcers : Associated with blood group O

questions.text: Which of the following is not a direct branch of celiac trunk ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right hepatic artery is a branch of common hepatic artery Options: A, B and D: Direct branches of celiac trunk are : Left gastric artery, Common hepatic artery and Splenic artery.

questions.text: Stress-induced ulcers are most commonly found in the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Stress ulcer is a single or multiple mucosal defect which can become complicated by upper gastrointestinal bleeding physiologic stress. Ordinary peptic ulcers are found commonly in the gastric antrum and the duodenum whereas stress ulcers are found commonly in fundic mucosa and can be located anywhere within the stomach and proximal duodenum.

questions.text: Most common epithelial tumors of stomach is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common epithelial tumors of stomach is gastric polyps. It rarely transforms into gastric Ca. 2nd most common epithelial tumors of stomach is Carcinoid. Option C. GIST arises from mesenchymal cells from the interstitial cells of cajal.

questions.text: Finney stricturoplasty is done when the length of the bowel stricture is ?
questions.solution: Correct answer (D) Finney strictureplasty is indicated for strictures up to 15 centimeters. The Finney Strictureplasty is performed by folding the diseased bowel on itself and creating a large opening between the two loops. This stricturoplasty can be used to address longer strictures (>10 cm and ≤15 cm) than those manageable with the Heinke-Mikulicz technique (usually performed for strictures up to 10 cm.

questions.text: Hour glass stomach is seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hourglass stomach is a deformity of the stomach in which the ‘waist’ is constricted by fibrosis caused by a chronic peptic ulcer, producing an upper and a lower cavity separated by a narrow channel.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of hypergastrinemia ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Atrophic gastritis) is the most appropriate cause of hypergastrinemia due to its chronic nature. Atrophic gastritis involves the long-term damage of the stomach lining, often due to autoimmune processes or chronic H. pylori infection, which leads to the destruction of parietal cells responsible for acid secretion. As a result, gastric acid production is severely reduced, and the body compensates by increasing gastrin levels in an attempt to stimulate more acid secretion. Unlike PPI-induced hypergastrinemia, which is usually temporary and reversible once the medication is stopped, atrophic gastritis causes persistent hypergastrinemia because the damage to the stomach lining is ongoing. This makes atrophic gastritis a more chronic and sustained cause of elevated gastrin levels, making it the most appropriate answer in this context.

choices.text: Anterior branch of vagus at pylorus
Anterior branch of vagus at cardiac.

questions.text: Criminal nerve of Grassi:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A branch of the right posterior vagus which passes to the left behind the oesophagus, ending in the gastric cardia.

questions.text: Peritoneal dissemination of gastric cancer can be best detected by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Peritoneal dissemination of the gastric cancer can be best detected by laparoscopy. Option A. Abdominal USG can a primary test in the evaluation of gastric ca. Endoscopic USG that is EUS is the best investigation for looking at the local invasion or the T stage of Gastric Ca. Option D. MRI is the preferred investigation which is used for lymph node spread of the tumour

choices.text: Involvement of mucosa, submucosa and muscularis
Involvement of mucosa, submucosa and adjacent lymph nodes

questions.text: All the following indicates early gastric cancer except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Early gastric cancer (EGC) is defined as invasive gastric cancer that invades no more deeply than the submucosa, irrespective of lymph node metastasis (T1, any N). Classification system used for early gastric cancer is Japanese Classification

questions.text: Irish Lymph node is commonly seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) An Irish node is an enlarged left anterior axillary lymph node, often associated with advanced gastric cancer.

questions.text: H. pylori causes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Type A Gastritis : Autoimmune disease and it is associated with pernicious anaemia Type B Gastritis: Associated with H. Pylori infection

questions.text: How many lymph node stations are removed in D2 Gastrectomy ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There are 3 types of Gastrectomy D1, D2 and D3 In D1 Gastrectomy: We remove lymph node stations from LN 1 to LN 6 In D2 Gastrectomy: We remove lymph node stations from LN 1 to LN 11 In D3 Gastrectomy : We remove lymph node stations from LN 1 to LN 16.

questions.text: A 36-years-old woman is hospitalized for treatment of a stomach ulcer that has been getting progressively worse over several months. Radiographic studies reveal the site of involvement to be along the greater curvature, approximately 4 cm away from the pyloric sphincter. That night, the ulcer perforates, and there is considerable intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgery reveals that the ulcer has eroded through the stomach wall and has damaged the artery supply in the involved region of the stomach. Which artery was likely involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The right gastroepiploic artery, branch of the gastroduodenal artery, supplies the right half of the greater curvature of the stomach and could be directly affected by ulceration of the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: A gastric biopsy is performed on a 42 years old man. As the pathologist inspects the specimen, he observes numerous, normal cuboidal-to-columnar cells with apical membrane-bound secretory granules in the gastric glands. From which area of the stomach was the biopsy specimen most likely taken?
questions.solution: Correct answer (C) The pathologist saw normal chief cells, which are abundant in the body and fundus of the stomach. Chief cells secrete pepsinogen, which is stored in apical membrane-bound granules. The parietal (oxyntic) cells are large, pyramidal, and acidophilic cells with central nuclei (like a "fried egg"). They make and Secrete HCI. The mucous neck cells secrete mucus and appear clear. The enteroendocrine cells have affinity for silver stains and exhibit a positive chromaffin reaction. these cells synthesize amines, polypeptides, or proteins.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female accountant complains of severe epigastric pain and is admitted to the hospital. A gastroscopic examination reveals a small, perforated ulceration in the posterior wall of the greater curvature of her stomach. An upright chest radiograph reveals a small amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity. Where is the air most likely located?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The right subphrenic space is located between the inferior aspect of the diaphragm and the superior surface of the liver. An ulceration in the posterior stomach wall would allow the passage of air from the stomach into the right subphrenic space through an open communication in the omental bursa. The remaining answer choices are located inferior to the site of ulceration and would not accumulate air.

choices.text: Parietal peritoneum and the greater omentum
Lesser omentum and the gastrosplenic ligament

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals guarding and rigidity in the abdominal wall. An abdominal CT scan shows a thrombus in an intestinal artery supplying the ileum. Which of the following layers of peritoneum will have to be entered by the surgeon to access the affected vessel?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The parietal peritoneum lines the abdominal wall, whereas the visceral peritoneum is in intimate contact with organs. The greater omentum extends from the greater curvature of the stomach and covers the midgut. Access to the ileum would require penetration of the parietal peritoneum to enter the peritoneal cavity and interruption of the visceral peritoneum of “the mesentery” covering the thrombosed vessel. Although it would probably be necessary to reflect the greater omentum for adequate exposure, it would not ordinarily require an incision

choices.text: Partial excision with marsupialisation can be done for large cysts or those lying at the root
Sclerotherapy can be done using 10% glucose solution
A segment of bowel resection is almost always required

questions.text: A 40 years old man presented with a painless abdominal lump, located in the umbilical region, which became less prominent on raising the legs, with positive Tillaux’s sign. CT scan was done which is shown below. The contents of the lump were aspirated under USG guidance. The aspirate was milky in appearance. False about the management of this condition is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cysts may occur in the mesentery of either the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following: Chylolymphatic, Enterogenous ,Urogenital remnant (actually retroperitoneal but project into peritoneum) and Dermoid CHYLOLYMPHATIC CYST is the most common variety, probably arising in congenitally misplaced lymphatic tissue that has no efferent communication with the lymphatic system. The thin wall of the cyst, which is composed of connective tissue lined by flat endothelium, is filled with clear lymph or, less frequently, with chyle, varying in consistency from watered milk to cream. More often unilocular than multilocular, a chylolymphatic cyst is almost invariably solitary. Chylolymphatic cyst has a blood supply that is independent from that of the adjacent intestine and, thus, enucleation is possible without the need for resection of gut. ENTEROGENOUS CYSTS - The content is mucinous and either colourless or yellowish brown as a result of past haemorrhage. The muscle in the wall of an enteric duplication cyst and the bowel with it is in contact have a common blood supply; consequently, removal of the cyst always entails resection of the portion of intestine. The most common presentation of a mesenteric cyst is of a painless abdominal swelling with characteristic physical signs there is a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus the swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery (Tillaux’s sign)

choices.text: Left gastric artery arises from the coeliac trunk
Right gastric artery arises from common hepatic artery
The blood supply of the mucosa of the lesser curvature arises from the submucosal plexus
Short gastric vessels supply the fundus

questions.text: True about blood supply of stomach are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The blood supply to the mucosa of the lesser curvature arises directly from the left and right gastric vessels rather than from a submucosal plexus. Therefore, they have to travel a long course and the lack of a submucosal plexus in the lesser curvature are responsible for the development of lesser curvature ischemia and perhaps ulceration.

choices.text: Antral alkalinization leading to inhibition of somatostatin release
Upregulation of parietal cell acid production

questions.text: Helicobacter pylori infection primarily mediates duodenal ulcer pathogenesis via
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Helicobacter pylori possess the enzyme urease, which converts urea into ammonia and bicarbonate, thus creating an environment around the bacteria that buffers the acid secreted by the stomach. H. pylori infection is associated with decreased levels of somatostatin, decreased somatostatin messenger RNA production, and fewer somatostatin-producing D cells. These effects are probably mediated by H. pylori-induced local alkalinization of the antrum (antral acidification is the most potent antagonist to antral gastrin secretion), and H. pylori mediated increases in other local mediators and cytokines. The result is hypergastrinemia and acid hypersecretion, presumably leading to the parietal cell hyperplasia seen in many patients with duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A subtotal gastrectomy with D2 dissection performed for Stage 3 gastric adenocarcinoma in the antrum includes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Generally, the surgeon strives for a grossly negative margin of at least 5 cm. More than 15 resected lymph nodes are required for adequate staging, even in the low-risk patient. In the absence of involvement by direct extension, the spleen and pancreatic tail are not removed. Reconstruction is usually by Billroth-I gastrojejunostomy or Roux-en-Y reconstruction.

choices.text: NSAID cessation and urea breath test

questions.text: A 55-year-old executive who is seen because of severe epigastric pain is found on esophagogastroduodenoscopy to have a large ulcer in the duodenal bulb and tests positive for H. pylori. He is treated for H. pylori and instructed to quit smoking, but his symptoms persist and he is referred to you for further management. At this time, it would be most appropriate to recommend
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The indications for surgery in PUD are bleeding, perforation, obstruction, and intractability or nonhealing. Intractability should be an unusual indication for peptic ulcer operation nowadays. The patient referred for surgical evaluation because of intractable PUD should raise red flags for the surgeon: maybe the patient has a missed cancer, is noncompliant, or has Helicobacter despite the presence of a negative test or previous treatment.

questions.text: The standard treatment for an isolated 3 cm gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) in the body of the stomach is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prognosis in patients with GISTs depends mostly on tumor size and mitotic count, and metastasis, when it occurs, is typically by the hematogenous route. Any lesion >1cm can behave in a malignant fashion and may recur. Thus, all GISTs are best resected along with a margin of normal tissue—wedge resection with clear margins is adequate surgical treatment. Imatinib, a chemotherapeutic agent that blocks the activity of the tyrosine kinase product of c-kit, yields excellent results in many patients with metastatic or unresectable GIST, and is also recommended in high risk groups as an adjuvant therapy.

choices.text: Have better outcomes than type I and II tumors

questions.text: Type III gastric carcinoid tumors
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Type III gastric carcinoids are sporadic tumors, most often solitary (usually >2 cm), occur more commonly in men, and behave more aggressively than types I and II. Unlike types 1 and II, they are not associated with hypergastrinemia. Type I gastric carcinoids are the most common type of gastric carcinoid, and occur in patients with chronic hypergastrinemia secondary to pernicious anaemia or chronic atrophic gastritis. Type II is rare, and is associated with MEN1 and ZES.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with malena and anemia requiring recurrent blood transfusion underwent upper G.I. endoscopy. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The parallel red stripes atop the mucosal folds of the distal stomach is suggestive of watermelon stomach. Histologically, gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated mucosal blood vessels that often contain thrombi, in the lamina propria. Beta blockers and nitrates, useful in the treatment of portal hypertensive gastropathy, are ineffective in patients with gastric antral vascular ectasia. Antrectomy may be required to control blood loss, and this operation is quite effective but carries increased morbidity in this elderly patient group. Patients with portal hypertension and antral vascular ectasia should be considered for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPSS).

choices.text: H. pylori eradication therapy can resolve symptoms
Total gastrectomy may be indicated for bleeding

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who presented with epigastric pain, weight loss, diarrhea, and hypoproteinemia underwent upper G.I. endoscopy. What is false regarding the management of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a case of Ménétrier disease. it is characteristically associated with protein losing gastropathy and hypochlorhydria. There are large rugal folds in the proximal stomach, and the antrum is usually spared. A few patients with this unusual disease have been successfully treated with the epidermal growth factor receptor blocking monoclonal antibody cetuximab. Most patients with Ménétrier’s disease are middle-aged men who present with epigastric pain, weight loss, diarrhea, and hypoproteinemia. There may be an increased risk of gastric cancer. Sometimes, the disease regresses spontaneously. Occasionally it is associated with H pylori infection, and the disease improves with helicobacter eradication. Total gastrectomy may be indicated for bleeding, severe hypoproteinemia, or cancer.

choices.text: Organoaxial rotation is less common than mesenteroaxial
Contrast study is superior than endoscopy

questions.text: A patient presents with severe epigastric pain, retching without vomiting. Attempt to pass a nasogastric tube failed. What is false regarding this condtion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute volvulus of the stomach is associated with epigastric pain, retching without vomiting and inability to pass a nasogastric tube. This is known as the Borchardt triad. Rotation of the stomach usually occurs around the axis and between its two fixed points, i.e. the cardia and the pylorus. Rotation can occur in the horizontal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) direction but, commonly, it is the former which occurs. This condition is usually associated with a large diaphragmatic defect around the oesophagus (paraoesophageal herniation). An acute presentation with ischaemia may occur. Endoscopically, it can be extremely difficult to sort out the anatomy, and this is one situation in which the contrast radiograph is superior. It is advisable to separate the stomach from the transverse colon and then perform an anterior gastropexy to fix the stomach to the anterior abdominal wall.

choices.text: Proximal part of stomach is plicated around the lower oesophagus

questions.text: False regarding Nissen Fundoplication is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nissen fundoplication is the most commonly performed surgery for GERD. It is the re-creation of a sphincter around the EGJ, done by wrapping the fundus around the esophagus. Fundoplications • Nissen’s—total 360° • Toupet’s—partial 180°—posterolateral • Watson’s—partial 120°—anterolateral • Dor—anterior fundoplication • Partial fundoplication with mesh wrap around

questions.text: A 73-y/o female presents with acute onset of abdominal distention, pain, nausea and vomiting. She has no previous surgeries. She has no abdominal or inguinal hernias on examination. Abdominal x-ray shows dilated small bowel with air-fluid levels and pneumobilia. The obstruction is most likely at which site?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gallstone ileus is a rare cause of intestinal obstruction. The most common etiology is erosion of a large gallstone into the duodenum via a cholecystoduodenal fistula, where the stone passes in the GI tract until it obstructs at the ileocecal valve. Other, less common, locations of fistulas include cholecystogastric and cholecystocolic, which can cause gastric outlet obstruction and colonic obstruction, respectively. After resuscitation, the priority is relieving the obstruction by removing the stone. Concomitant cholecystectomy and closure of the fistula during the index operation or a two-step staged operation are described in the literature

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the ED with complaints of epigastric abdominal fullness and occasional pain over the past 8 months with associated nausea. He confirms a long-standing history of acute on chronic pancreatitis secondary to alcohol abuse. A CT scan from a prior admission 10 months ago showed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. In the ED, he has one episode of blood-tinged emesis. He remains hemodynamically stable, with a hemoglobin of 10 g/ dL. A CT scan is obtained. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This patient has a diagnosis of splenic artery pseudoaneurysm with a likely fistulous connection to a pancreatic pseudocyst. His nausea is likely due to gastric compression from this pseudocyst. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, IR embolization of the aneurysm to prevent further bleeding is the most appropriate next step in management, followed by surgical cystogastrostomy once his bleeding risk is controlled.

questions.text: The patient comes to the emergency department 6 months after surgery complaining of a 2-day history of epigastric abdominal pain and emesis without relief. In the emergency department her temperature is 98.9°F with a pulse of 99 beats/min and blood pressure of 140/70 mmHg. Her abdomen is soft with mild distention, normal bowel sounds, and vague discomfort on palpation. CT of the abdomen reveals the passage of oral contrast to the colon without evidence of free fluid, extravasation of contrast, or pneumoperitoneum. The excluded stomach and the entire length of the biliopancreatic limb are dilated. The biliopancreatic limb appears to be in its normal location. The patient will most likely require which one of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This patient has a late complication manifested as obstruction of the biliopancreatic limb because of stenosis of the jejunojejunostomy and will probably require revision of the anastomosis. Other late complications include gastrojejunostomy stricture or internal hernias. Internal hernias can be difficult to diagnose but are repaired by reduction and primary closure. Many surgeons advocate closure of all mesenteric defects at the time of the original operation to reduce the risk for internal hernia formation.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a history of projectile, non-bilious vomiting for the past 5 days. The baby appears dehydrated, and laboratory investigations reveal the following: • Sodium: 132 mmol/L (low) • Potassium: 2.8 mmol/L (low) • Chloride: 85 mmol/L (low) • pH: 7.55 (alkalosis) Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is MOST characteristic of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia Pathophysiology of Metabolic Abnormality in IHPS: • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting leads to the loss of gastric contents rich in hydrochloric acid (HCl). • This results in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to: o Loss of hydrogen ions (H?) in vomitus. o Retention of bicarbonate (HCO??) in the blood as the kidneys try to compensate for volume loss. • Hypokalemia occurs due to: o Renal compensation: Aldosterone secretion is stimulated in response to hypovolemia, leading to potassium excretion in exchange for sodium retention. o Intracellular shift of potassium as hydrogen ions move out of cells to counteract alkalosis.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting since birth. An abdominal X-ray reveals the following sign. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Duodenal atresia The double bubble sign is a radiological finding seen on an abdominal X-ray and is most commonly associated with duodenal atresia. It refers to the appearance of two air-filled structures: 1. Proximal stomach 2. Dilated proximal duodenum The absence of distal bowel gas indicates a complete obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain worsens after meals. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the BEST investigation to confirm the diagnosis of a gastric ulcer and rule out malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the evaluation of peptic ulcers, especially gastric ulcers. It provides direct visualization of the ulcer, allows for the differentiation between benign and malignant ulcers, and facilitates biopsy for histopathological evaluation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with sudden-onset severe epigastric pain. He has a history of long-standing epigastric discomfort and occasional use of NSAIDs. On examination, he has tachycardia, hypotension, and guarding in the abdomen. Which of the following is the most common complication of peptic ulcers?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most common complication of peptic ulcers is bleeding. Peptic ulcers can erode into blood vessels, especially arteries like the gastroduodenal artery, leading to upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Bleeding presents with symptoms like hematemesis (vomiting blood) or melena (black, tarry stools). While perforation, gastric outlet obstruction, and penetration are also serious complications, bleeding is the most frequent. Incorrect Options: A. Perforation: Perforation is a dangerous complication and can present with sudden severe abdominal pain, peritonitis (guarding, rigidity), and signs of shock. In this particular patient's clinical story (sudden severe pain + guarding), perforation is very likely happening now, but in general, perforation is not the most common complication overall — bleeding is. If they ask about THIS SPECIFIC PATIENT’S current condition ? ? The patient has sudden severe pain, guarding, hypotension ? this is classical for perforation. (So, clinically for this man’s current problem, perforation is most likely happening right now.) C. Gastric outlet obstruction: This is a late complication of chronic ulcers leading to scarring and narrowing of the pyloric channel. It presents with vomiting of undigested food, early satiety, and weight loss, but it is much less common than bleeding. D. Penetration: Penetration occurs when the ulcer burrows into adjacent organs (like pancreas, liver). It presents with persistent severe pain, but again, it is less common than bleeding.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent epigastric pain, chronic diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past 6 months. He has been treated for multiple episodes of peptic ulcers in the past, but symptoms have recurred despite regular use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). Laboratory tests reveal a fasting gastrin level of 1200 pg/mL (normal: <100 pg/mL). What is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Zollinger-Ellison syndrome Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES) is a rare condition caused by a gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma), which leads to excessive gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer disease. Key clinical features and diagnostic findings support this diagnosis.

choices.text: Between the esophagus, stomach, and spleen
Between the cystic duct, duodenum, and pancreatic body
Between the porta hepatis, neck of the pancreas, and third part of the duodenum
Between the liver, spleen, and greater curvature of the stomach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent, refractory peptic ulcer disease is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES). Imaging studies are planned to localize the gastrinoma. Which of the following anatomical regions is referred to as Passaro's Triangle, where most gastrinomas are found?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Between the porta hepatis, neck of the pancreas, and third part of the duodenum Passaro's Triangle (also called the gastrinoma triangle) is an anatomical region where 90% of gastrinomas (tumors causing Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome) are located. Understanding this triangle is crucial for localizing gastrinomas during diagnostic imaging and surgery. Boundaries of Passaro's Triangle: 1. Superiorly: Junction of the cystic duct and the common bile duct (near the porta hepatis). 2. Medially: Neck of the pancreas. 3. Inferiorly: Third part of the duodenum. This triangular area is significant because most gastrinomas (sporadic or associated with MEN1) are found within its boundaries.
